Article.ArticleTitle: Ozonation using a stainless-steel membrane contactor: Gas-liquid mass transfer and pharmaceuticals removal from secondary-treated municipal wastewater.

AbstractText: A tubular porous stainless steel membrane contactor was characterized in terms of ozone-water mass transport, as well as its application in removing 23 pharmaceuticals (PhACs) detected in the secondary-treated municipal wastewater, under continuous mode operation. The volumetric mass transfer coefficient (K<sub>L</sub>a) was evaluated based on liquid flow rate, gas flow rate, and ozone gas concentration. The K<sub>L</sub>a values were substantially improved with an increment in liquid flow rate (1.6 times from 30 to 70 dm<sup>3</sup> h<sup>-1</sup>) and gas flow rate (3.6 times from 0.30 to 0.85 Ndm<sup>3</sup> min<sup>-1</sup>) due to the improved mixing in the gas-liquid interface. For the lowest liquid flow rate (30 dm<sup>3</sup> h<sup>-1</sup>), the water phase boundary layer (82%) exhibited the major ozone transfer resistance, but it became almost comparable with membrane resistance for the highest liquid flow rate (70 dm<sup>3</sup> h<sup>-1</sup>). Additionally, the influence of the specific ozone dose (0.39, 0.53, and 0.69 g O<sub>3</sub> g DOC<sup>-1</sup>) and ozone inlet gas concentration ( [Formula: see text]  = 27, 80, and 134 g Nm<sup>-3</sup>) were investigated in the elimination of 23 PhACs found in secondary-treated municipal wastewater. An ozone dose of 0.69 g O<sub>3</sub> g DOC<sup>-1</sup> and residence time of 60 s resulted in the removal of 12 out of the 23 compounds over 80%, while 17 compounds were abated above 60%. The elimination of PhACs was strongly correlated with kinetic reaction constants values with ozone and hydroxyl radicals (k<sub>O3</sub> and k<sub>HO</sub><sup>•</sup>), leading to a characteristic elimination pattern for each group of contaminants. This study demonstrates the high potential of membrane contactors as an appealing alternative for ozone-driven wastewater treatment.
